Award.AwardTitle: Broadening Participation Research Project: Advancing Interest and Motivation (AIM) for STEM Careers

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Abstract ? Award Number 1505098

Livingstone College is completing the implementation of an HBCU-UP Broadening Participation Research in STEM Education project to examine the impact of the Advancing Interest and Motivation (AIM) model on student career interests, motivation, self-efficacy, career outcome expectations, and employment outcomes in STEM. The PIs also propose a supplemental study using structural equation modeling and path analysis to study self-regulation and its influences on STEM career interests and progression. AIM is designed for Livingstone College juniors and seniors from the biology, mathematics, and computer information systems departments in collaboration with the Office of Career Services and STEM faculty. The research framework is based on social cognitive career theory. The research design will incorporate pre- and post-tests of students? career development orientations using quantitative surveys to measure the effectiveness of the career development program. The PIs will also employ a path model to examine the theoretical relationships explicated by social cognitive career theory.

The project will inform STEM teaching and career development intervention strategies. The findings could contribute to the current body of information regarding phenomena associated with STEM majors that do not pursue STEM careers, an important aspect to understand in trying to increase the representation of minorities in the STEM workforce.

The proposal was evaluated following the merit review process in accordance with procedures and criteria stated in the NSF Grant Proposal Guide. On March 25-26, 2013, a review panel of STEM education and research experts reviewed the proposal based on National Science Board approved criteria as well as specific criteria stated in the program solicitation (NSF 13-516).

POR.DRECONTENT:
The purpose of the broadening participation research project, Advancing Interest and Motivation (AIM) for STEM Careers, was to develop, implement, and study a STEM career development program for Livingstone College students in collaboration with Clemson University's Charles H. Houston Center for the Study of the Black Experience in Education. The research study utilized a quantitative methodology as well as qualitative procedures to examine the impact of a theory-based academic engagement program designed to prepare historically Black college and university (HBCU) students to pursue a STEM career. The career development program, AIM for STEM Careers, enabled participants to meet STEM career professionals, practice STEM job search skills, produce resumes, generate cover letters, and discuss career opportunities to enhance students’ career self-efficacy. AIM for STEM Careers also included interactive workshops and presentations conducted by STEM faculty, STEM professionals, and the Office of Career and Professional Development at Livingstone College. 

The research team utilized quantitative and qualitative instruments to assess the effects of the program. Data from the qualitative survey demonstrated that program activities increased students’ awareness of strategies to pursue a STEM job. Analysis of the quantitative data indicated that diagnostic interpretations were more meaningful than group comparisons. Based on these research findings, the research team developed the STEM Workforce Training Laboratory and the STEM Career Development Laboratory. The STEM Workforce Training Laboratory enables students to practice laboratory protocols and problem-solving skills to prepare for the STEM workforce. The STEM Career Development Laboratory allows STEM students to produce job search documentation and study career exploration information. Several AIM for STEM Careers participants work in entry-level STEM positions or pursue a graduate degree in STEM suggesting that program components enhanced broadening participation outcomes. During the project, the research team also created a new conceptual framework called STEMployable to describe useful instructional activities that prepare students to attain a STEM job. STEMployable skills are essential job competencies that students must demonstrate before graduation to enhance employment outcomes.
